items.title: Server can now be stopped under Linux
items.body: Maybe I missing something, but without that I don't know how to restart the server. (BindFailed error)

items.title: Should ignore main.swift only in the Sources folder
items.body: Feels a bit more clean.

items.title: Better View errors handling
items.body: Server will throw 404 if `View` file was not found.

items.title: I think handling line breaks this was is less error prone.
fix query values in params
items.body:
if you have an url like

```
http://localhost:8080/data/5?query=test&hello=now
```

the value for request.parameters was

```
5?query=test&hello=now
```

this fix, force this value avoiding any query string to be appended.

Now the value is only

```
5
```

items.title: Add deployment info for Heroku
items.body: Having info about Heroku deployment might help people who are not interested in spending too much time on setting up environments.

items.title: Fixing swift errors on heroku server & public access control in some places
add MIT License
items.body: It is (c) Tanner Nelson - I assume that is your name :)

items.title: Routing based on Hostname version 2
items.body:
Second attempt to implement (see #17 )

One thing - I'm not sure about the code in `NodeRouter.search()`. I feel we should try to find matching route in the domain-specific tree first and if we find it, we should not even bother to go through the `"*"` ones. 

What do you think?

items.title: Decode percent encoded strings in parameters
items.body:
This is a simple PR that decodes strings using `stringByRemovingPercentEncoding` before inserting them into parameters. Almost every web server does this automatically. 

I was unsure of what to do with regards to tests, as I didn't see existing tests for the parameters. If I could get feedback on that, I would love to write tests if needed.

items.title: comment out printTree()
items.body: Some debug stuff left uncommented by mistake

items.title: Nested Routes
items.body:
Ok, this is now working on Ubuntu (via docker) and I have added tests for simple (single) and nests resources. 

I also simplified the path construction  by removing the Zip2Sequence which was unnecessarily verbose:

``` swift
let fullPath = components.enumerate()
    .map { $1 + "/" + params[$0] }
    .joinWithSeparator("/")
```

Addresses #44 which I think makes valid points.

items.title: Lw/branch router driver
items.body:
This is an alternative approach to the existing branch system w/ very few modifications.  In current performance metrics, the original implementation takes over 35% longer.  The speed bonus can be useful in routing multiple requests and maintaining efficiency.  The structure I added is very close to the original, also based on a trie, but the lookup is done in a linked fashion by traversing a branch as opposed to a search which is where most of the boost appears to derive.
## Performance
### Branch Router - 1.513

![screen shot 2016-02-20 at 2 49 41 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5750489/13198858/2c992fd2-d7e2-11e5-9bf7-e4d0e5d3aa30.png)
### Node Router - 2.094

![screen shot 2016-02-20 at 2 53 19 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5750489/13198857/27c0cd9e-d7e2-11e5-9aa3-5d251007596a.png)
## Changes
#### Request Handler
- Renamed `Closure` to `RequestHandler` having it represent: `Request throws -> ResponseConvertible`.  I think this naming aids in clarity of intent.  It also might be worth nesting w/in request so it's `Request.Handler`.  I like both
#### Node Router

Becomes just Router and interfaces more directly with branches allowing request to forward outward recursively
#### Branch

Replace route, renamed to branch to be more symbolic about the linked structure.
#### RouterDriver

Slightly reworked protocol.  It is no longer necessary for the router to convert its throwing functions internally, instead allowing the Server to take care of it since it's doing it anyway. Removed optionality of `hostname` opting for default argument of `"*"` which feels a bit more _swifty_. We could also write an overload in RouterDriver extension that builds in the default to the protocol programmatically. The functions are converted at handle time as opposed to server start which allows us to omit the need for `register` and makes custom routers more convenient.

``` Swift
public protocol RouterDriver {  
  func route(request: Request) -> (Request -> Response)?        
  func register(hostname hostname: String?, method: Request.Method, path: String, handler: (Request -> Response))   
}
```

Becomes

``` Swift
public protocol RouterDriver {
    func route(request: Request) -> RequestHandler?
    func register(hostname hostname: String, method: Request.Method, path: String, handler: RequestHandler)
}
```
#### Global `Route`

The global `Route` accessor moves from class functions to an instance.  This allows for a couple of main things.  This does not affect familiar syntax in any way.
- No need to register a router driver with the routes, instead the router driver is self contained
- Allows the global `Route` object to be injected as a default which makes it easier for custom routers to be added if desired
### Syntax Implications

This would only affect users who created a default `RouterDriver` in which case, conversions should be extremely light.  All other syntax remains identical to end user
### ToDo
- [x] Integrate branch / router
- [x] Run performance tests
- [x] Confirm feature and expectation parity (does it run the same way and produce the same results) -- confirm w/ Tanner
- [x] Add `Controller` support back
- [x ] Cleanup
- [x] Rename `AltRouter` to `Router` -- named `Alt` during testing for easier distinction

items.title: adding cryptoswift
items.body:
`/Users/tanner/Developer/vapor/vapor/Packages/CryptoSwift-0.2.3/Sources/CryptoSwift/SHA2.swift:276:20: error: expression was too complex to be solved in reasonable time; consider breaking up the expression into distinct sub-expressions
            result += [UInt8(item & 0xff), UInt8((item >> 8) & 0xff), UInt8((item >> 16) & 0xff), UInt8((item >> 24) & 0xff),`

Getting this error when trying to add CryptoSwift.

items.title: Logger - new PR
items.body: It was easier to close the previous PR and resubmit this on Master. Note to self.. Xcode conflicts are a pain.

items.title: fixing not parsing form encoded values
Protocolize Controller
items.body:
I felt like Controller would be best served as a Protocol with default implementations. This would remove the restriction of subclassing Controller directly.

Unfortunately, I couldn't get the Xcode Project or the unit tests to run, but this does build.

This would be a breaking change for existing implementations of Controller in that they would have to remove their `override` keyword, but I feel like it's not very substantial.

items.title: Dependency cleanup
items.body:
This adds the JSON serializer and SHA256 Cryptography into Vapor without dependencies.

It also cleans up some `Route` logic.

items.title: Travis & Linux tests
items.body:
- modified travis.yml to run tests on both linux and os x
- using prerelease swiftpm to run xctests on both platforms
- added VaporExample target/executable, debuggable from Xcode
- now full development from Xcode is possible
- tidied up the project

Moved from #72.

items.title: add application abort and route groups
Make session data access more direct
items.body: Minor change to make session access more direct & abstract the underlying data structure

items.title: Environment Support
Integrated Jay as the new JSON library
items.body:
- works on both OS X and Linux
- I reused the existing convenience type Json and convert between it and Jay's internal type-safe structure
- tested both get and post on both platforms, added those to the VaporDev test executable
- this net removes over 600 LOC from the project

Happy to hear any feedback!

At the moment I didn't check in the folder Packages, but since the only supported way is building with `swift build`, we're not adding any extra work on the developers.

@LoganWright @tannernelson Please review.

items.title: Added vapordev command
items.body: Added a vapordev command based on https://github.com/qutheory/vapor/pull/80 but in pure swift

items.title: Lw/public ip argument
items.body:
Publicizing IP for optional customization.  Everything still defaults to `0.0.0.0`, but offers an alternative for special use cases.

Also added a few knick knacks:
- [x] Moved process to more abstracted argument extraction
- [x] Added argument tests
- [x] Added optional IP variable
- [x] Replaced lingering print statements w/ appropriate logs
